title: Proportion of variation that cannot be explained

content.question: The least-squares regression model <math alttext="y hat equals, negative 3.4 plus 5.2 times x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>^</mo></mrow></mover><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>âˆ’</mo><mn>3.4</mn></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>5.2</mn><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and correlation coefficient <math alttext="r equals negative 0.66" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mi>r</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mrow> <mn>0.66</mn> </mrow> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> were calculated for a set of bivariate data with variables <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Which of the following is closest to the proportion of the variation in <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that cannot be explained by the explanatory variable?

skill.text: Skill 2.C: Calculate summary statistics, relative positions of points within a distribution, correlation, and predicted response.
